name: Northern Helmeted Curassow
description: It has a stocky body, small head, and relatively long tail. Above its forehead is a curved, bluish horny casque. It exhibits two color morphs: the more common is almost entirely black with a metallic sheen, white underbelly, and tail tip; sometimes the female is rufous with a black head and dark spotting. Feathers on the chest are elongated, forming a mantle.
image_alt: Northern helmeted curassow, photo: Tomáš Adamec, Prague Zoo
proportions: Length 80–100 cm, tail 30.4–36.2 cm; wing length 36.3–42.7 cm; weight 2.6–3.6 kg
attractions: It stays deep in the forest on steep slopes and gorges. Active by day, pairs or small family groups forage on the ground. In danger or at night, it flies into tree canopies. Courtship is notable, with the male enticing the female by offering food in his beak. Both parents care for the young.
projects_note: The northern helmeted curassow is listed as vulnerable on the IUCN Red List. Its population is declining due to hunting for meat and its horny casque, as well as habitat loss.
